123.text:
{{Infobox tree
| name = Webster Sycamore
| image =Webster Sycamore Webster Springs WV 1955.jpg
| alt = A black and white image of the Webster Sycamore with four men standing around the base of its trunk
| image_caption = A photograph of the Webster Sycamore published in ''[[Castanea (journal)|Castanea]]'' (1955) with four men standing at the base of its trunk, demonstrating the scale of the large tree
| native_name =
| native_name_lang =
| species = [[Platanus occidentalis|American sycamore]]
| binominal = ''Platanus occidentalis''
| location = Near [[Webster Springs, West Virginia|Webster Springs]], [[Webster County, West Virginia|Webster County]], [[West Virginia]]
| coordinates =
| seeded = before 1508 AD
| felled = 2010
| custodian = Purdee and Curtin Lumber Company
}}
The '''Webster Sycamore''' (alternatively known as the '''Webster Springs Sycamore''' and the '''Big Sycamore Tree''') was an [[Platanus occidentalis|American sycamore]] (''Platanus occidentalis'') in the [[U.S. state]] of [[West Virginia]]. Long recognized for its size, the Webster Sycamore was the largest living American sycamore tree in West Virginia until its [[felling]] in 2010. The tree stood approximately {{convert|4.5|mi|km}} east of [[Webster Springs, West Virginia|Webster Springs]] in [[Webster County, West Virginia|Webster County]], in a moist flood plain along the banks of the Back Fork Elk River, a tributary stream of the [[Elk River (West Virginia)|Elk River]].

The Webster Sycamore reached a [[tree height measurement]] of {{convert|112|ft|m}}, a [[tree crown measurement]] of {{convert|90|ft|m}}, and a circumference of {{convert|25.75|ft|m}} at [[diameter at breast height|breast height]]. In 1955, the [[American Forests|American Forests Association]] declared the tree the largest of its species in the United States. It only held the title for three weeks, before the association identified a larger American sycamore in [[Maryland]]. Despite losing its national title, the sycamore remained the largest American sycamore in West Virginia. Following a 1963 survey of large trees in West Virginia, the Webster Sycamore was named the second-largest tree after a [[white oak]] (''Quercus alba'') in [[Randolph County, West Virginia|Randolph County]].

The land upon which the Webster Sycamore was located was owned by the Pardee and Curtin Lumber Company, which spared the tree during its [[lumber]] operations in the area during the 1950s. [[West Virginia University]] biologist W. H. Gillespie averred that the tree stood as "a memorial of the original virgin forest". The Pardee and Curtin Lumber Company preserved the land surrounding the tree as a park, known as Big Sycamore Park. During the annual events Webster Wildwater Weekend in April and the Webster County Nature Weekend in May, hiking excursions were led to the Webster Sycamore.

On September 3, 2007, a malicious fire was set in the base of the Webster Sycamore's trunk. The tree survived the blaze, but suffered irreparable damage. The [[West Virginia Division of Forestry]] performed a safety and risk assessment of the tree, and determined that structural mitigation was not feasible, and that the Webster Sycamore was to be "considered an extreme hazard". In January 2008, a 17-year-old suspect from [[Bergoo, West Virginia|Bergoo]] was formally charged with a [[felony]] count of [[arson]] for setting fire to the tree. Following the fire, experts recommended that the Webster Sycamore be felled or fenced off as a safety measure. According to the Division of Forestry, the tree was finally brought down during the summer of 2010. At the time of its death, the tree was estimated to be over 500 years old.

== Geography and setting ==
[[File:Cumberlandplateaumap.png|upright|thumb|right|A map illustrating the [[Allegheny Mountains|Allegheny Mountain Range]] in relation to the [[Allegheny Plateau]] and [[Cumberland Mountains|Cumberland Mountain Range]] of the [[Appalachian Mountains]]|alt=A map illustrating the Allegheny Plateau and the Allegheny and Cumberland mountain ranges of the Appalachian Mountains]]
Prior to the arrival of [[European American]] [[settler]]s and [[Exploration|explorers]], the [[Allegheny Mountains|Allegheny Mountain Range]] of the [[Appalachian Mountains]] was overlaid with [[old-growth forest]]s consisting predominantly of [[deciduous]] [[hardwood]] trees, which were characterized by individual trees of enormous size and girth.<ref name = "Lewis1">{{Harvnb|Lewis|1998|p=18.}}</ref><ref name = "Abramson1">{{Harvnb|Abramson|Haskell|2006|p=81.}}</ref> The [[Platanus occidentalis|American sycamore]] (''Platanus occidentalis'') was one of the species of trees that proliferated throughout these old-growth forests.<ref name = "Lewis1"/> American sycamores can grow at least {{convert|100|ft|m}} in [[Tree height measurement|height]] and the species is distributed throughout the [[Eastern United States]].<ref name = "WVDC1">{{cite press release |author=  |title=Sycamore: A Hardy and Popular Shade Tree | url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-268431528.html |location=[[Charleston, West Virginia]] |publisher=[[West Virginia Department of Commerce]] |date=September 30, 2011 |accessdate=October 5, 2015 | via=[[HighBeam Research]] | subscription=yes}}</ref><ref name = "Core1">{{Harvnb|Core|1950|p=62.}}</ref> It usually thrives in moist soils along streams, especially in sandy [[loam]] soils.<ref name = "WVDC1"/><ref name = "Core1"/><ref name = "Hicks1">{{Harvnb|Hicks|1998|p=166.}}</ref> American sycamores are a dominant species in [[Upland and lowland (freshwater ecology)|bottomland]] and [[Riparian forest|riparian]] forests.<ref name = "Abramson2">{{Harvnb|Abramson|Haskell|2006|p=63.}}</ref> The species is present throughout every county in [[West Virginia]], and is most abundant along the state's streams.<ref name = "WVDC1"/><ref name = "Core1"/>

Formerly West Virginia's largest American sycamore, the Webster Sycamore (alternatively known as the Webster Springs Sycamore and the Big Sycamore Tree) was located in a moist flood plain along the banks of the [[Back Fork Elk River]], a tributary stream of the [[Elk River (West Virginia)|Elk River]], in [[Webster County, West Virginia|Webster County]].<ref name = "TCG1">{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Authorities investigate arson at landmark tree | newspaper = [[Charleston Gazette-Mail|The Charleston Gazette]] | publication-place = [[Charleston, West Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date =September 4, 2007 | page = | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-13966166.html | accessdate = October 5, 2015|via=[[HighBeam Research]] | subscription=yes}}</ref><ref name = "CDM3">{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Community briefs | newspaper = [[Charleston Daily Mail]] | publication-place = [[Charleston, West Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = April 23, 2008 | page = | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-16306536.html | accessdate = October 5, 2015|subscription=yes| via=[[HighBeam Research]] }}</ref><ref name = "Gillespie1">{{Harvnb| Gillespie |1955|p=72.}}</ref> The tree was located approximately {{convert|4.5|mi|km}} east of [[Webster Springs, West Virginia|Webster Springs]].<ref name = "Hannah1">{{Harvnb|Hannah|Brashears|2007|p=1.}}</ref><ref name = "CDM1">{{cite news| last =Smith  | first = Charlotte Ferrell | author-link =| title =Teen charged with burning historic tree | newspaper = [[Charleston Daily Mail]] | publication-place = [[Charleston, West Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = January 15, 2008 | page = | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-15106985.html | accessdate =October 5, 2015|subscription=yes | via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}</ref>

== Dimensions, age, and recognition ==

=== Dimensions and age ===
Various measurements were taken of the tree during the latter part of its lifetime; however, measurements of the [[circumference]] differ. In 1955, the tree's circumference at [[Diameter at breast height|breast height]], when measured {{convert|4.5|ft|m}} from the ground, was {{convert|24|ft|8|in|m|cm}}.<ref name = "Gillespie2">{{Harvnb| Gillespie |1955|p=73.}}</ref> At a [[tree fork]] {{convert|45|ft|m}} from the ground, its trunk measured {{convert|4.33|ft|m}} in diameter.<ref name = "Gillespie2"/> The trunk stood to a height of {{convert|82|ft|m}}, where it had been decapitated by a previous windstorm.<ref name = "Gillespie2"/> The tree's horizontal canopy spread measured approximately {{convert|75|ft|m}} in width.<ref name = "Gillespie2"/> The lowest limb of the sycamore was {{convert|23.5|ft|m}} from the ground, and measured {{convert|2|ft|m}} in diameter.<ref name = "Gillespie2"/> According to official measurements in 1963, however, the diameter at breast height of the Webster Sycamore, when measured {{convert|4.5|ft|m}} from the ground, was more than {{convert|7|ft|m}} and its circumference measured {{convert|23|ft|m}}.<ref name = "SGM1">{{cite news| last =Blizzard  | first = William C.  | author-link =| title =Big Sycamore on Back Elk: Webster giant carries piggy-back partner. | newspaper = [[Charleston Gazette-Mail|Sunday Gazette-Mail]] | publication-place = [[Charleston, West Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = May 17, 1964 | page = 20m | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/40541598/ | accessdate =October 5, 2015 | via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}}</ref> The sycamore was estimated to be at least {{convert|120|ft|m}} in height.<ref name = "SGM1"/> Its trunk measured approximately {{convert|5|ft|m}} in diameter when measured {{convert|90|ft|m}} from the forest floor.<ref name = "SGM1"/>

According to the West Virginia Division of Forestry and West Virginia Humanities Council in 2002 and the West Virginia Big Tree Program in 2011, the Webster Sycamore was the largest American sycamore in West Virginia, with a height of {{convert|112|ft|m}}, a [[tree crown measurement]] of {{convert|90|ft|m}}, and a circumference of {{convert|25.75|ft|m}} at breast height.<ref name = "CDM4">{{cite news| last = Smith | first = Charlotte Ferrell | author-link =| title =Officials want to update W.Va. Big Tree Program's registry; As third-most-forested state in nation, keeping track of W.Va.'s big trees not as easy as it sounds | newspaper = [[Charleston Daily Mail]] | publication-place = [[Charleston, West Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = May 11, 2011 | page = | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-28655144.html | accessdate = October 5, 2015 |subscription=yes|via=[[HighBeam Research]] }}</ref><ref name = "CDM5">{{cite news| last = Smith | first = Charlotte Ferrell | author-link =| title =Five state trees up for national recognition | newspaper = [[Charleston Daily Mail]] | publication-place = [[Charleston, West Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = July 29, 2002 | page = | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-9869835.html | accessdate = October 5, 2015 | subscription=yes|via=[[HighBeam Research]] }}</ref><ref name = "SGM2">{{cite news| last =Byers  | first = Robert J.  | author-link =| title =Living history: Nominations sought for trees with story to tell | newspaper = [[Charleston Gazette-Mail|Sunday Gazette-Mail]] | publication-place = [[Charleston, West Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = June 23, 2002 | page = | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-14732116.html | accessdate = October 5, 2015 |subscription=yes|via=[[HighBeam Research]] }}</ref>

By the time of its felling in 2010, the Webster Sycamore was estimated to be over 500 years in age.<ref name = "TCG1"/><ref name = "CDM1"/><ref name = "CDM4"/>

=== Other physical characteristics ===
In 1955, an [[Tsuga canadensis|eastern hemlock]] (''Tsuga canadensis'') measuring {{convert|5.5|ft|m}} in height grew from a rotten [[Wood#Knots|knothole]] in the tree's main south fork.<ref name = "Gillespie2"/> By 1963, the hemlock that had taken root in the tree's south fork remained.<ref name = "SGM1"/> In describing the growth of the hemlock from an upper tree fork of the Webster Sycamore, writer William C. Blizzard referenced the idiom of [[Pelion]] piled upon [[Mount Ossa (Greece)|Ossa]].<ref name = "SGM1"/> No [[tree hollow]]s or visible outer blemishes were reported on the sycamore at that time; however, by 2007, the tree's trunk had developed an opening into its hollow center at its base, which allowed visitors to step inside of it.<ref name = "TCG1"/><ref name = "SGM1"/>

=== Recognition ===
[[File:Webster Sycamore Webster Springs WV 1920.jpg|upright|right|thumb| alt = A black and white image of an American sycamore, possibly the Webster Sycamore, taken around 1920 | An image of an American sycamore near Webster Springs published in ''Trees, Stars and Birds: A Book of Outdoor Science'' (1920)]]
The Webster Sycamore had long been a local landmark on account of its age and size, and was known locally as being the world's largest American sycamore.<ref name = "Gillespie1"/> By 1920, author Edwin Lincoln Mosely had included an image and a brief description of a similar American sycamore near Webster Springs – probably the Webster Sycamore – in his book ''Trees, Stars and Birds: A Book of Outdoor Science''.<ref name = "Mosely1">{{Harvnb|Mosely|1920|p=x.}}</ref>

It was in 1955 that the tree won recognition from the [[American Forests|American Forests Association]] as the largest tree of its species in the United States.<ref name = "Gillespie1"/> It only held the title for three weeks before a larger American sycamore in Maryland was discovered and recognized by the association.<ref name = "Gillespie1"/> Despite losing its national title, the sycamore remained the largest American sycamore in West Virginia.<ref name = "Gillespie2"/>

During the West Virginia Centennial "big-tree contest" of 1963, the honorific of the state's largest tree went to a [[Quercus alba|white oak]] (''Quercus alba'') near [[Huttonsville, West Virginia|Huttonsville]] in [[Randolph County, West Virginia|Randolph County]], thus beating out the Webster Sycamore.<ref name = "SGM1"/> The white oak measured {{convert|11.25|ft|m}} in diameter.<ref name = "SGM1"/> An [[elm]] (''Ulmus'') tree in [[Putnam County, West Virginia|Putnam County]] also bested the Webster Sycamore at {{convert|8|ft|m}} in diameter.<ref name = "SGM1"/>

During a speech to the [[United States Senate]] in honor of West Virginia Day on June 20, 2004, U.S. Senator [[Robert C. Byrd]] mentioned the Webster Sycamore while boasting of "the biggest and best of West Virginia".<ref name = "USC1">{{Harvnb|United States Congress|2004|p=12983.}}</ref>

== Preservation ==
The land upon which the Webster Sycamore was located was owned by the Purdee and Curtin Lumber Company of nearby Webster Springs.<ref name = "Gillespie1"/><ref name = "CDM1"/> The company spared the tree in the 1950s, during its [[lumber]] operations in the area.<ref name = "Gillespie2"/> According to [[West Virginia University]] biologist W. H. Gillespie in ''[[Castanea (journal)|Castanea]]'', the tree stood as "a memorial of the original virgin forest".<ref name = "Gillespie2"/> The Purdee and Curtin Lumber Company preserved the land surrounding the tree as a park, known as Big Sycamore Park.<ref name = "CDM1"/> The park was utilized by campers, and by tourists visiting the tree.<ref name = "CDM1"/> A [[swinging bridge]] across the Back Fork of Elk River provided access to the tree and the park.<ref name = "Hannah1"/>

In 2002, the Webster Sycamore was one of five trees nominated by the West Virginia Humanities Council to the National Register of Historic Trees, a registry of historic trees maintained by the American Forests Historic Tree Nursery.<ref name = "CDM5"/>

During the annual events Webster Wildwater Weekend in April and the Webster County Nature Weekend in May, hiking excursions were led to the Webster Sycamore, in addition to the nearby Three Falls of Back Fork.<ref name = "CDM3"/><ref name = "TCG2">{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Webster river races next month | newspaper = [[Charleston Gazette-Mail|The Charleston Gazette]] | publication-place = [[Charleston, West Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date =March 26, 2003 | page = | url =http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-13816656.html | accessdate = October 5, 2015 |subscription=yes|via=[[HighBeam Research]] }}</ref><ref name = "TBS1">{{cite news| last = Fletcher | first = Thomas R. | author-link =| title =Climbing the mountain and viewing the valley Weekend: The Webster County Nature Tour in early May offers a choice of hikes, from an easy walk to a strenuous trek, in scenic West Virginia | newspaper = [[The Baltimore Sun]] | publication-place = Baltimore | volume = | issue = | date =April 19, 1998 | page = | url = http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1998-04-19/features/1998109239_1_elk-mountain-elk-river-mountain-ridge | accessdate = October 5, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005154640/http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1998-04-19/features/1998109239_1_elk-mountain-elk-river-mountain-ridge |archive-date=October 5, 2015 }}</ref>

== Vandalism and death ==
On the afternoon of September 3, 2007, a malicious fire was set in the base of the Webster Sycamore's trunk.<ref name = "TCG1"/><ref name = "CDM1"/><ref name = "CDM2">{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Old tree in Webster target of arson | newspaper = [[Charleston Daily Mail]] | publication-place = [[Charleston, West Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = September 4, 2007 | page = | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-9983318.html | accessdate = October 5, 2015 |subscription=yes | via=[[HighBeam Research]] }}</ref> The fire burned up through the hollow center of the tree's hollow bole.<ref name = "TCG1"/><ref name = "CDM2"/> The Webster Springs Fire Department, Webster County Sheriff's Department, and the [[West Virginia Division of Forestry]] provided a joint response to the fire, and remained on the scene for several hours until the flames were out.<ref name = "TCG1"/><ref name = "CDM2"/> The tree survived the blaze but suffered irreparable damage.<ref name = "TCG1"/><ref name = "CDM2"/>

Initially following the fire, the tree's vicinity was closed for the investigation and for an assessment of the extent of damage and safety risk.<ref name = "TCG1"/><ref name = "CDM2"/> On September 27, 2007, the West Virginia Division of Forestry's urban forestry coordinator Bob Hannah and technical specialist Jennifer Brashears engaged in an inspection and evaluation of the tree to provide recommendations.<ref name = "Hannah1"/> In their report, Hannah and Brashears assessed that the tree's "severe structural weakness" was not caused by the fire, and instead highlighted the tree's "size, age, and severity of defects" as the cause of its instability.<ref name = "Hannah1"/> They did, however, assess that the fire may have caused further mortality of the tree's [[cambium]].<ref name = "Hannah2">{{Harvnb|Hannah|Brashears|2007|p=2.}}</ref> They used various measurements developed by the [[International Society of Arboriculture]] and the [[United States Forest Service]] to formulate a tree risk assessment.<ref name = "Hannah1"/> At the time of their investigation, the tree's diameter at breast height was {{convert|8.42|ft|m}}, with 27% of the trunk consisting of open space.<ref name = "Hannah1"/> Hannah and Brashears also found that one-third of the lower trunk and [[root crown]] demonstrated callus formation and no new growth, but instead severe decay and peeling bark.<ref name = "Hannah1"/> Hannah and Brashears further determined that structural mitigation was not feasible, and that the Webster Sycamore was to be "considered an extreme hazard" and the public should be "excluded from its striking zone through fencing and signage".<ref name = "Hannah1"/>

The investigation into the fire was led by the Division of Forestry's chief investigator, Sam Butcher.<ref name = "CDM1"/> The investigation lasted four months, and once a suspect had been identified, the case was turned over to the Webster County [[Prosecutor#United States|prosecuting attorney]]'s office.<ref name = "CDM1"/> Butcher credited Art Yagel, a Division of Forestry investigator, for bringing the investigation to its conclusion.<ref name = "CDM1"/> In January 2008, a 17-year-old suspect from [[Bergoo, West Virginia|Bergoo]] was formally charged with a [[felony]] count of [[arson]] for setting fire to the tree, while a second juvenile was also charged with a [[misdemeanor]] for providing false information to investigators.<ref name = "CDM1"/> The suspect was also charged with misdemeanor counts of providing false information to conservation officers, possession of [[marijuana]], and [[Alcohol consumption by youth in the United States|underage consumption of alcohol]].<ref name = "CDM1"/> The second juvenile was not involved in the setting of the fire.<ref name = "CDM1"/>

Following the fire, experts recommended that the Webster Sycamore be [[felling|felled]] or fenced off as a security measure.<ref name = "CDM1"/> According to the Division of Forestry, the tree was finally brought down during the summer of 2010.<ref name = "CDM4"/>

In recognition of the tree, the Health Policy Division of the Office of the West Virginia Insurance Commissioner considered the name "Sycamore Healthcare Exchange" as one of the naming options for West Virginia's [[health insurance marketplace]] in 2011, following the passage of the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]].<ref name = "HPD1">{{cite web | url = http://bewv.wvinsurance.gov/Portals/2/pdf/Insurance%20Exchange%20Name%20and%20Tag%20Options.pdf | title = WVINS-2225: Name and Tagline Options | last1 = | first1 = | work = Health Policy Division, Office of the West Virginia Insurance Commissioner website | publisher = Health Policy Division, Office of the West Virginia Insurance Commissioner | date = 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005154841/http://bewv.wvinsurance.gov/Portals/2/pdf/Insurance%20Exchange%20Name%20and%20Tag%20Options.pdf |archive-date=October 5, 2015 | accessdate = October 5, 2015}}</ref>

124.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2012}}
{{taxobox
 | image               = Zanthoxylum americanum.jpg
 | image_caption       = ''Zanthoxylum americanum''  at the [[Real Jardín Botánico de Madrid]]
 | regnum              = [[Plantae]]
 | unranked_divisio    = [[Angiosperms]]
 | unranked_classis    = [[Eudicots]]
 | unranked_ordo       = [[Rosids]]
 | ordo                = [[Sapindales]]
 | familia             = [[Rutaceae]]
 | genus               = ''[[Zanthoxylum]]''
 | species             = '''''Z. americanum'''''
 | binomial            = ''Zanthoxylum americanum'' 
 | binomial_authority  = [[Philip Miller|Mill.]]
 | range_map           = Zanthoxylum americanum range map.png
 | range_map_caption   = Natural range
}}

'''''Zanthoxylum americanum''''', the '''common prickly-ash''', '''common pricklyash''', '''common prickly ash''' or '''northern prickly-ash''' (also sometimes called '''toothache tree''', '''yellow wood''', or '''suterberry'''), is an aromatic shrub or small tree native to central and eastern portions of the United States and Canada. It is the northernmost New World species in the citrus ([[Rutaceae]]) family, and is part of the same genus as [[sichuan pepper]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://esp.cr.usgs.gov/data/atlas/little/zantamer.pdf |title=Zanthoxylum americanum |type=range map |publisher=[[U.S. Geological Survey]]}}</ref> It can grow to {{convert|10|m|ft|sp=us}} tall with a [[diameter at breast height]] (DBH) of {{convert|15|cm|in|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Duncan" /> It produces [[Biological membrane|membranous]] [[leaflet (botany)|leaflets]] and [[axil]]lary flower clusters.<ref name="Duncan">{{cite book|last1=Duncan|first1=Wilbur H.|last2=Duncan|first2=Marion B.|title=Trees of the Southeastern United States|publisher=The [[University of Georgia Press]]|location=Athens, Georgia|date=1988|pages=76–77|isbn=0-8203-1469-2}}</ref> The wood is not commercially valuable, but oil extracts from the bark have been used in traditional and [[alternative medicine|alternative]] medicine, and have been studied for [[Antifungal medication|antifungal]] and [[cytotoxic]] properties.<ref name="Duncan" />  The genus name is sometimes spelled ''Xanthoxylum.''

== Alternative names ==
''Zanthoxylum parvum'' is also known as Shinners' tickletongue and small prickly-ash.

==Taxonomy==
Originally described by [[Scotland|Scottish]] botanist [[Philip Miller]] in 1768,<ref name="IPNI">{{IPNI | id = 775568-1 | accessdate =July 5, 2009}}</ref> ''Zanthoxylum americanum'' is a member of the wide-ranging [[genus]] ''[[Zanthoxylum]]'' in the plant family [[Rutaceae]], which includes many species with aromatic foliage. Miller, who spelled the name ''Xanthoxylum'', described the plant in the eighth edition of his ''[[The Gardeners Dictionary|Gardeners Dictionary]]'', as "grow[ing] naturally in Pensylvania{{sic}} and Maryland".<ref name="Miller">{{cite book|last=Miller|first=Philip |authorlink=Philip Miller|title=The Gardeners Dictionary: Containing the Best and Newest Methods of Cultivating and Improving The Kitchen, Fruit, Flower Garden, and Nursery; As also for Performing The Practical Parts of Agriculture: Including the Management of Vineyards, With The Methods of Making and Preserving Wine, According to the present Practice of The most skilful Vignerons in the several Wine Countries in ''Europe''. Together With Directions for Propagating and Improving, From Real Practice and Experience, All Sorts of Timber Trees|url=http://www.botanicus.org/title/b12066618|edition=Eighth|year=1768|publisher=Printed for the Author|location=London}}</ref>

==Description==
The plant has pinnately compound leaves with 5–11 membranous [[leaflet (botany)|leaflets]]. It has axillary flower and fruit clusters.<ref name="Duncan" /> The buds are hairy. The dark green leaves are bitter-aromatic, with [[crenate]] margins.<ref name="Duncan" /><ref name="wildflower" /> The stalked follicles are green and then turn red<ref name="wildflower" /> through deep blue through black.<ref name="Duncan" /><ref name="Grieve" /> Flowers are [[dioecious]], with yellow-green petals.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Claud L.|first2=L. Katherine |last2=Kirkman|title=Trees of Georgia and Adjacent States|publisher=[[Timber Press]]|location=Portland, Oregon|date=1990|pages=163–164|isbn=0-88192-148-3}}</ref>

''Zanthoxylum parvum '' is a rhizomatous and [[deciduous]] plant. It is a [[dioecious]] shrub and can grow up to 2 m tall. Stems have erect prickles, sometimes curved, which occur either solitary or paired; they range from 4-13mm long. ''Zanthoxylem parvum '' are imparapinnate with alternate leaves and average about 7–13 leaflets. The [[rachis]] and [[petiole (botany)|petioles]] are not winged. 
Leaflets are opposite, usually oval shaped with a tapering point or sometimes [[ovate]] or [[lanceolate]]; the leaflets range from 6–16(−35) mm long and 11–18 mm wide with an obtuse apex and a triangular attaching to a stem [[cuneate leaf|cuneate]]. They are pellucid-punctate along crenulate margins and are pubescent on and between veins.

Flowers appear as umbrella-like clusters from 2–12 in small terminal to axillary umbellate clusters. They are imperfect with [[pedicel (botany)|pedicel]]s 2–4 m long; there are 4–5 petals, elliptic to ovate-oblong 1.6–1.9 mm long and have green with reddish hairs near the tips; stamens 5; ovary with 2–5 carpels.

Fruit a follicle, with 2 seeds per carpel.

==Distribution and conservation status==
[[File:Zanthoxylum americanum - USDA.jpg|thumb|''Zanthoxylum americanum'' berries]]
Rare in the [[Southern United States|South]], it is more common in the northern United States.<ref name="Duncan" /> In the United States, it occurs in Alabama, Arkansas, Connecticut, Delaware, the District of Columbia, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Maryland, Maine, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, North Carolina, North Dakota, Nebraska, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Ohio, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Virginia, Vermont, Wisconsin and West Virginia; the species also occurs in [[Ontario]] and [[Quebec]] in Canada.<ref name="usda" /> The species is listed as [[Endangered]] in Florida, Maryland, and New Hampshire; and as [[Special Concern]] in Tennessee.<ref name="usda">{{cite web|url=http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=ZAAM|title=PLANTS profile for ''Zanthoxylum americanum'' Mill. (common pricklyash)|work=[[Natural Resources Conservation Service]]|publisher=[[United States Department of Agriculture]]|accessdate=July 3, 2009}}</ref>

Butterflies that use ''Zanthoxylum americanum'' as a larval food source include the [[Papilio thoas|Thoas swallowtail (''Papilio thoas'')]], [[Papilio cresphontes|giant swallowtail (''P. cresphontes'')]], and [[Papilio troilus|spicebush swallowtail (''P. troilus'')]].<ref name="wildflower">{{cite web|url=http://www.wildflower.org/plants/result.php?id_plant=ZAAM|title=NPIN: Zanthoxylum americanum (Common pricklyash)|accessdate=July 3, 2009}}</ref>

This plant was discovered by [[John Bartram]] in his travels and plant collecting excursions.{{Citation needed|date=November 2011}}

=== ''Zanthoxylum parvum'' ===

==== Habitat ====
Underlies of maple-oak woodlands or dense growth of small trees like evergreen oak on rocky, often shallow, well-drained, [[tuff]] or other igneous rock, at elevations of {{convert|1350|-|1750|m}}.

The [[understory]] is primarily native bunchgrasses with a mix of other cacti and herbaceous species. In shaded dense areas, the ground is sparsely inhabited with vegetation but covered with dense leaf litter.

====Phenology====
''Zanthoxylum parvum'' flowers in late March until early April, before its leaves have expanded fully. Although foliage is present throughout most of the year it eventually becomes deciduous and turns yellow in mid-October.

====Comments====
''Zanthoxylum parvum'' is a rare and poorly understood plant from a few populations in the [[Davis Mountains]]

==Medicinal use==
[[File:Common pricklyash.jpg|thumb|Seedling drawing]]

===Traditional===
An oil extracted from the [[bark]] and follicles of the prickly-ash (both this species and ''[[Zanthoxylum clava-herculis]]'') has been used in [[herbal medicine]].<ref name="Duncan" /><ref name="Grieve" /> The extract may act as a [[stimulant]], and historic medicinal use has included use "for chronic [[rheumatism]], [[typhoid]] and skin diseases and impurity of the blood..." as well as for digestive ailments.<ref name="Grieve">{{cite book|last=Grieve|first=Mrs. M.|authorlink=Maud Grieve|title=[[A Modern Herbal]]|editor-first=Mrs. C. F. | editor-last=Leyel | editorlink=Hilda Leyel |publisher=Barnes & Noble Books|location=New York|origyear=1973|year=1996|pages=70–71|isbn=0-88029-921-5}}</ref> [[Maud Grieve|Grieve]] states, "The berries are considered even more active than the bark, being [[carminative]] and [[antispasmodic]], and are used as an [[aperient]] and for [[dyspepsia]] and indigestion; a fluid extract of the berries being given, in doses of 10 to 30 drops."<ref name="Grieve" /> The bark has been chewed for toothaches, and a tea from the follicles has been used for sore throats and as a [[diuretic]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Foster|first1=Steven|first2=James A.|last2=Duke|authorlink2=James A. Duke|title=A Field Guide to Medicinal Plants: Eastern and Central North America|publisher=[[Houghton Mifflin Company]]|location=Boston|date=1990|series=[[Peterson Field Guides|The Peterson Field Guide Series]]|pages=238|isbn=0-395-35309-2}}</ref> As noted by Michael Dirr, in his ''Manual of Woody Landscape Plants'', "Supposedly the stems and fruits were chewed by the Indians to alleviate toothache for the acrid juice has a numbing effect."{{Cite quote|date=November 2011}}

=== Modern studies and uses ===
There have been some modern studies of the oil's chemical constituents and their [[Antifungal medication|antifungal]]<ref>{{cite journal | first=N. |last=Bafiyeboa |title=Antifungal constituents of Northern prickly ash, Mill. | journal=Phytomedicine | volume=12 | issue=5 | pages=370–377 | doi=10.1016/j.phymed.2003.12.005 | pmid=15957372 | date=May 2005}}</ref> and [[cytotoxic]] effects.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ju|first1=Yong|first2=Cecil C. |last2=Still|first3=John N. |last3=Sacalis |first4=Jiangang |last4=Li |first5=Chi-Tang |last5=Ho |date=July 30, 2001|title=Cytotoxic coumarins and lignans from extracts of the northern prickly ash (''Zanthoxylum americanum'')|journal=[[Phytotherapy Research]]|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]|volume=15|issue=5|pages=441–443|url=http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/85007146/abstract?CRETRY=1&SRETRY=0|accessdate=July 3, 2009|doi=10.1002/ptr.686|pmid=11507740}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Saqib|first1=Q. N. |first2=Y.-H. |last2=Hui |first3=J. E. |last3=Anderson |first4=J. L. |last4=McLaughlin|date=January 11, 2006|title=Bioactive furanocoumarins from the berries of ''Zanthoxylum americanum''|journal=Phytotherapy Research|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|volume=4|issue=6|pages=216–219|url=http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/112228703/abstract|accessdate=July 3, 2009|doi=10.1002/ptr.2650040604}}</ref>

In 2012, [[Philadelphia Distilling|a Pennsylvania distillery]] introduced a [[bitters]] called Bartram's Bitters that uses prickly ash bark as one of several botanical ingredients. The concoction was based on a recipe for "Bartram's Homestead Bitters" that was found in a book that belonged to the family of botanist [[John Bartram]].<ref>{{cite news |title=The resurrection of Bartram's Bitters |first=Rick |last=Nichols |url=http://articles.philly.com/2012-05-25/news/31839493_1_cocktail-bitter-almond-gentian-root |newspaper=Philadelphia Inquirer |date=May 25, 2012 |accessdate=June 15, 2013}}</ref>
